awd_titl_txt: Using the Hexadehydro-Diels-Alder (HDDA) Reaction for the Facile Synthesis of Elaborated Polycyclic Aromatics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division of the NSF supports the project by Professor Thomas R. Hoye. Professor Hoye is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Minnesota. He is developing new chemical reactions that allow for the synthesis of novel molecules known as polycylic aromatics. These molecules are valuable for a variety of reasons, one being their potential for use in optoelectronic devices such as the organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) and photovoltaic cells that are used in energy efficient displays, lighting units, and for the conversion of solar energy into electricity. By developing a fundamental understanding of the new reactions used to make polycyclic aromatics, Professor Hoye and his coworkers may push the chemical reactions toward the synthesis of compounds having previously unknown chemical structures and, in the future, build new materials with improved properties. A number of significant broader impacts of benefit to a wide group of stakeholders result from the project. Of particular note are research opportunities for undergraduate research students, a tutorial on the practical separation of complex organic mixtures, and new extensions of the Minnesota State Fair exhibit on "Sustainable Polymers."

Professor Hoye's research group is capitalizing on the tremendous potential for the hexadehydro-Diels-Alder (HDDA) reaction cascade to provide for the rapid chemical synthesis of manifold classes of highly conjugated polycyclic aromatics. Some are of value to the field of organic electronic and photonic materials research.  Collaborations are in place to pursue early phases of such development. It is the methods and strategies for the syntheses of such compounds that are the most important 'products' that are emerging from this project. Preliminary results demonstrate that the synthetic routes are often remarkably short and efficient. New and fundamentally important mechanistic knowledge is also emerging. Advances in the benzyne chemistry include new aspects of cycloaddition reactions, two-directional benzyne trapping, and controlled oligomer synthesis. A process dubbed the 'domino-HDDA reaction' is particularly intriguing. Professor Hoye holds major teaching awards that recognize his career-long commitment to the education of students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Outreach activities supported by this project benefit chemistry research students at multiple levels and contribute to the education of the public in the arenas of green chemistry and sustainable polymers. The scientific advances have the possibility of opening new avenues for pursuit by materials scientists who use organic electronic and photonic compounds in the settings of light-emitting diodes, photovoltaics, and solar cells.  These applications have a large potential for societal impact.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Thomas R. Hoye, Department of Chemistry, University of Minnesota

The funding provided by this National Science Foundation (NSF) grant has enabled significant development of an area of research known as the hexadehydro-Diels-Alder (or HDDA) reaction. This is a process by which readily available reactants (tri-alkynes, aka triynes) engage one another to generate an isomeric, highly reactive intermediate known as a benzyne. Impressively, the process can be made to occur simply by heating the triyne reactant (or HDDA substrate). 

Benzynes are a subset of a broader class of highly reactive species called arynes. They react with a wide variety of trapping agents almost the instant they are formed to produce a wide variety of products. The ability of the HDDA process to create the benzynes in the absence of any additional reagents other than the trapping agent provides the means i) to make new compounds that have unusual structural features, ii) to discover previously unprecedented modes of reaction, and iii) to gain understanding about the underlying fundamental principles of how the final prod?ucts are formed: i.e., the reaction mechanisms.

With the support of this three-year research grant, we were able to make a number of new discoveries. These have been described in peer-reviewed publications in the scientific literature that acknowledge the (full or partial) support by this NSF award. A graphical abstract for each of #1-15 below can be seen in the three .png images uploaded with this report. In addition, publicly accessible versions of the publications for each can be accessed at the NSF Public Access Repository (PAR) https://par.nsf.gov/search/term:%22hoye,%20thomas%22. The term(s) between "s in each of #1-15 can be used to search for the title of each manuscript in the PAR listing.

#1  We showed that the benzyne can be trapped through "intramolecular capture" of an appended furan ring to form medium-sized rings. 

#2  Surprisingly, potential HDDA tri- and tetrayne substrates connected by a four-atom linker undergo preferential formation of "cyclobutadienes" rather than benzynes. 

#3  "The domino hexadehydro-Diels-Alder" reaction features up to four successive intramolecular HDDA events in which each intermediate aryne becomes the diynophile for the next-in-line 1,3-diyne. 

#4  Unusual "isomerization" processes of a type we call oxa-tetrahydro-Diels-Alder reactions led to intermediate dihydropyrans that ring-opened to products having a rearranged skeleton.

#5  Cu(I)-catalyzed "bromoalkynylation" reactions of the reactive HDDA benzynes were discovered.

#6  A remarkable role of a boron atom to serve as a mediator of carbene-like reactivity of the benzyne in "BF3-promoted" reactions was discovered. 

#7  We showed that unusual "benzoxetenonium" ions could be accessed, leading to another class of reactive intermediates known as ortho-quinomethides.

#8  A "one-pot, three-aryne" cascade process was developed in which a 1,2-bisbenzyne precursor was used to trap an initial benzyne #1 in a net SN2' fashion to produce benzyne #2, which became the diynophile for the final HDDA producing the third, HDDA-benzyne.

#9  We published a major review of HDDA chemistry that summarizes the developments to date of the thermal cycloisomerizations of "tethered triynes".

#10  "Coumarins" were shown to be convenient trapping agents for HDDA-benzynes that, following carbon dioxide ejection, lead to phenanthrene derivatives.

#11  In another "Cu(I)-catalyzed" trapping process, the benzyne can be converted directly into a new triyne substrate for a second HDDA reaction.

#12  We discovered that the HDDA benzyne can fuel the formation of a rare S(IV)-"sulfurane" intermediate enroute to products having multicyclic, helical architectures.

#13  One-pot "radial" HDDA processes, involving up to six separate HDDA events, can lead to products having an array of polycyclic aromatic arms emanating from a central core template.

* In a broader impact activity, we are creating a set of "Vignettes in Physical Organic Chemistry." These will be well-crafted, pedagogical documents for audiences ranging from second semester undergraduate through mid-level graduate students of organic chemistry and as a resource for instructors and advisers of those learners. One prototype, this for the Criegee Mechanism for Ozonolysis of Alkenes, can be seen as the final two graphical images on this Project Outcomes Report site. We hope to expand this activity with continuing NSF support into an active website that the entire community can access and find benefit.


Last Modified: 06/24/2022
Modified by: Thomas R Hoye

Project Outcomes Report

Thomas R. Hoye, Department of Chemistry, University of Minnesota

The funding provided by this National Science Foundation (NSF) grant has enabled significant development of an area of research known as the hexadehydro-Diels-Alder (or HDDA) reaction. This is a process by which readily available reactants (tri-alkynes, aka triynes) engage one another to generate an isomeric, highly reactive intermediate known as a benzyne. Impressively, the process can be made to occur simply by heating the triyne reactant (or HDDA substrate). 

Benzynes are a subset of a broader class of highly reactive species called arynes. They react with a wide variety of trapping agents almost the instant they are formed to produce a wide variety of products. The ability of the HDDA process to create the benzynes in the absence of any additional reagents other than the trapping agent provides the means i) to make new compounds that have unusual structural features, ii) to discover previously unprecedented modes of reaction, and iii) to gain understanding about the underlying fundamental principles of how the final prod?ucts are formed: i.e., the reaction mechanisms.

With the support of this three-year research grant, we were able to make a number of new discoveries. These have been described in peer-reviewed publications in the scientific literature that acknowledge the (full or partial) support by this NSF award. A graphical abstract for each of #1-15 below can be seen in the three .png images uploaded with this report. In addition, publicly accessible versions of the publications for each can be accessed at the NSF Public Access Repository (PAR) https://par.nsf.gov/search/term:%22hoye,%20thomas%22. The term(s) between "s in each of #1-15 can be used to search for the title of each manuscript in the PAR listing.

#1  We showed that the benzyne can be trapped through "intramolecular capture" of an appended furan ring to form medium-sized rings. 

#2  Surprisingly, potential HDDA tri- and tetrayne substrates connected by a four-atom linker undergo preferential formation of "cyclobutadienes" rather than benzynes. 

#3  "The domino hexadehydro-Diels-Alder" reaction features up to four successive intramolecular HDDA events in which each intermediate aryne becomes the diynophile for the next-in-line 1,3-diyne. 

#4  Unusual "isomerization" processes of a type we call oxa-tetrahydro-Diels-Alder reactions led to intermediate dihydropyrans that ring-opened to products having a rearranged skeleton.

#5  Cu(I)-catalyzed "bromoalkynylation" reactions of the reactive HDDA benzynes were discovered.

#6  A remarkable role of a boron atom to serve as a mediator of carbene-like reactivity of the benzyne in "BF3-promoted" reactions was discovered. 

#7  We showed that unusual "benzoxetenonium" ions could be accessed, leading to another class of reactive intermediates known as ortho-quinomethides.

#9  We published a major review of HDDA chemistry that summarizes the developments to date of the thermal cycloisomerizations of "tethered triynes".

#10  "Coumarins" were shown to be convenient trapping agents for HDDA-benzynes that, following carbon dioxide ejection, lead to phenanthrene derivatives.

#11  In another "Cu(I)-catalyzed" trapping process, the benzyne can be converted directly into a new triyne substrate for a second HDDA reaction.

#12  We discovered that the HDDA benzyne can fuel the formation of a rare S(IV)-"sulfurane" intermediate enroute to products having multicyclic, helical architectures.

#13  One-pot "radial" HDDA processes, involving up to six separate HDDA events, can lead to products having an array of polycyclic aromatic arms emanating from a central core template.

* In a broader impact activity, we are creating a set of "Vignettes in Physical Organic Chemistry." These will be well-crafted, pedagogical documents for audiences ranging from second semester undergraduate through mid-level graduate students of organic chemistry and as a resource for instructors and advisers of those learners. One prototype, this for the Criegee Mechanism for Ozonolysis of Alkenes, can be seen as the final two graphical images on this Project Outcomes Report site. We hope to expand this activity with continuing NSF support into an active website that the entire community can access and find benefit.
